The Senate candidate was kicking off the first day of his “No B.S.” tour across Ohio, where seven similarly wealthy Republicans are competing in a primary for retiring GOP Sen.
Vance, who is running for U.S. Senate in Ohio, said stock trading should be off-limits for lawmakers, but wouldn't say what he would do with own his assets if elected.
Vance also told HuffPost that he doesn’t know whether he would back Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell for majority leader if Republicans retake the chamber.
“I think it should be illegal for members of Congress to trade stocks in this country,” the Republican said at a town hall event on Thursday.
“I think the problem that we have in the Republican Party is really deep, and it affects membership and affects leadership,” Vance said.
Vance said lawmakers should be banned from trading stocks while in office, joining a cause gaining momentum on both sides of the aisle.
He owns stakes in companies in a variety of sectors, including tech and health care, and between $50,000 and $100,000 in Walmart stock.
